Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Investigating the Influence of Halogen Ligands on the Ability of Late Gas-Phase Transition Metal Ions to Activate Bonds in Small Substrate Molecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project supported by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor William Taylor of the University of Central Arkansas and his undergraduate research team are studying reactions between small molecules and ions which both contain atoms of halogen elements (the halogens include fluorine, chlorine, bromine and iodine). The ions contain transition metal elements (for example copper, nickel or gold). Many important industrial processes today involve catalysts that contain transition metal atoms. The studies in Professor Taylor's laboratory thus inform the broader area of catalysis, which is a key part of the production of an estimated 90% of all chemical products. Catalytic processes have a tangible environmental benefit by either direct remediation of pollutants or by reducing the environmental burden of industrial chemical production. Undergraduates participating in this work benefit from a valuable research experience that increases retention rates in the sciences, and prepares them for a variety of career choices.

The project explores the influence of electronic modifications to metal centers via the ligand environment on bond activation in neutral molecules. Studies addressed in this project examine the chemistry of MX+ (M=Ni, Cu, Au; X=F, Cl, Br, I) with a number of halogenated compounds known to be potent greenhouse gases and ozone depleters. In addition, reactions of CuX+ and AuX+ (X=Cl, F) with methane are examined in order to explore low-energy processes leading to the functionalization of this abundant, yet relatively inert, chemical resource. All reactions are studied experimentally in the gas phase using a selected ion drift cell reactor which generates transition metal ions in a sputtering glow discharge source. These metal ions are then be chemically modified with the addition of the desired halogen, mass selected, and introduced into a drift cell containing the neutral reactant molecule of interest. Analysis of reaction products is carried out using a second quadrupole. Experimental results are complemented computationally with density functional calculations and MP2 theory to gain additional insights into possible reaction mechanisms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The chemistry that was the subject of this NSF-funded work focused on understanding factors relevant to fundamental catalytic processes. Representing approximately 30% of world GDP annually, catalytic processes are involved in the production of an estimated 80% of all manufactured products. In addition, catalytic processes have a tangible environmental benefit by either direct remediation of pollutants or by reducing the environmental burden of industrial chemical production. By furthering our understanding of the interactions between transition metal centers and molecular substrates, the work funded by this grant will increase our understanding of how catalysts function and can be controlled. In addition to exploring possible methods for enhancing the performance of commercial catalytic processes, this work also has a direct relationship to atmospheric processes involving anthropogenic greenhouse gases. In order to fully understand the environmental fates of these species, it is necessary to evaluate their reactions with metal ions that exist within the mesosphere arising from cosmic dust and meteors. This work also has implications extending beyond the terrestrial environment. Reactions of metal centers examined in this project have a direct relationship to chemistry thought to contribute to species occurring within the atmosphere of Titan. Our previous work focused on the effect that energizing the metal center has on reaction outcomes. Those results showed that such modifications to the metal center could elicit dramatic variation in the observed chemistry. The work funded by this grant expands on those observations by probing the effect of attaching an additional atom to the metal center on reactive behavior relevant to catalysis. All reactions studied here were examined using a specialized apparatus located in our laboratory which enabled us to precisely control the energetic conditions under which they occurred.  Selected reactions were also explored using computational modelling techniques. Results obtained in this work reveal that, dependent on the metal center, an otherwise inert metal can be made to be reactive simply by binding a suitable “modifier” atom to it. This raises the possibility that cheaper, less toxic catalysts might be possible with the appropriate chemical modifications. Although the discovery of new science has been the major factor in driving this research, involving students in the research process has also been a high priority.  The studies described above have provided an excellent vehicle for training undergraduates in methods of scientific inquiry and communication of their results.
